The fried appetizers are decent- I like the zucchini and mushrooms but not so much the mozzarella sticks.  The salad bar is an option.  The beer and wine is CHEAP.  If you want ice cream after your meal that is a third line you wait in.

What a fun and unique dining/entertainment experience in the Phoenix metro area!  My parents came to visit, so we decided to head out one night when it opened to catch the first two performances and eat some pizza and ice cream.  The food was surprisingly good and the entertainment was top notch - really fun way to spend an evening!

Im in Phoenix visiting family for a week and thought that I should take the boys here. I remember going here when I was younger and generally enjoyed the atmosphere. For those that have never been, Organ Stop Pizza boasts of the worlds largest Wurlitzer theater organ. Whats the difference between a theatre organ and regular organ you ask? To put it simply, one operator and and entire acoustic orchestra at his fingertips; from a full jazz drum set, grand piano, upright piano, clave, marimba, horns etc. and the operator plays them ALL. It is a sight to see.  This is a large building, designed like to be like an old theatre. When you come in pay attention to the exterior of the building as you can see some of the components used to operate the organ. The 32' diaphones and the turbine blower facility are all visible from the exterior. Parking is a breeze.  As you enter the building you come the the main counter where you immediately see the food menu. To your right is the bathrooms and the ATM. Pizza prices start at $5.49 to $18.99. After we placed our order the woman kindly advised us, we needed to go around the corner to pay for drinks, and CASH ONLY! PLEASE USE THE ATM. My stepfather and I looked at one another in total disbelief that a place of this size would not have a credit card machine. Maybe it is some mafia stuff, to get more money using their ATM. Crazy mentality none-the-less.  Finding a seat on the lower level, during peak times,  that will accommodate someone in powered chair is difficult. With this being centralized around snow-birds (retirees who travel to warmer climates during winter) you would think that they would have someone seating everyone and managing pedestrian traffic but that is not the case. After roughly 15 minutes we were able to find a seat that would accommodate our party and waited another 10 for our pizza. If you look towards the ceiling you will see a numerical board with numbers that can be illuminated. Look for your number and head to the counter to get your pizza.  Their pizza is great and it has a nostalgic feeling and taste to it.

Let me start by saying if this review is solely on food, it would be a fail and probably 1 star. The only redeemable aspect of the food for me was the fried mushrooms. That's saying a lot for a "pizza restaurant". Let's face it the pizza is on par with Little Caesars and Cici's but 3-4x the price.   Now to the positives. Realistically people do not come here for the food, or at least shouldn't. The draw here is the atmosphere, music, and pipes. Essentially, you have a very busy, loud cafeteria without the rude lunch ladies. Everyone is very helpful and polite though. The service is semi self serve but they do a very good job at busing the tables. Word of advice for people who want to bring small children, bring hearing protection as it can get very loud with some of the song selections.   As to the actual entertainment, it is very enjoyable and is interactive with song requests. Honestly, the organ is the only redeemable quality to this place and that saddens me because I would love frequent it more but the food quality puts this restaurant in the category of only when 'Rents come into town, which is once a year at best.

Bad Pizza, very bad pizza... I think most people are being very generous to say it's OK. I love the atmosphere here, the organ is great... Very bad pizza. I can only imagine how great this "once every 5 year" place could be if they had even "good" pizza, it would not even have to be great! Another yelp-er, compared this place to going to the grand canyon, you know, something you got to do.  I agree you need to go here... I actually brought my own pizza from Old Chicago, the last time I went... No one even tried to stop us. I think the wait staff understood, every time they passed our table they smiled. We got ice cream for desert and also left a big tip... This place has Pizza in it's name I would give more stars if they called it Organ World and charged for admission.

This is a very cool place to visit every few years.  The kids love it and the food does is as is expected.  It can get a bit crowded and their ordering methods are a bit outdated.    Make sure that you bring cash!

Loved the music - best part of the visit - quite entertaining, nice selection of songs.  Great for kids, our little ones (potentially grumpy from too much pool time) danced around to the music, played some arcade games; adults could visit.  The pizza was not so great in my opinion - we had one meat combo and a pepperoni.  Sort of like Chuck E Cheese -  overly dry (Really could have used more sauce and cheese), and the toppings weren't the best quality.  Salad bar was okay - a bit overpriced.  It was a good choice for the family, but the pizza was not the draw.

This review is just for service. Came here with my husband and kids on a Sunday at 2:30 in the afternoon. Starving. Never ate here, but heard about it so we wanted to check it out. Drove over to Mesa and walked in to be instantly turned away. So rude. The guy acted as if we were going to set a bomb off in the place! Came running over and told us that we have to wait a half hr before we can be seated. OK. I'm starving, but we came all the way here so we will wait. There is a game room for the kids and a bench for us to sit and wait. NOPE. Not allowed  to wait in the building at all.  His older man that was panicking that we were there came up to us and told us we have to leave the entire building. This place is pretty big too... I don't see how us hanging in the game room is bothering them while they do whatever they need to do to prepare the dining room. Made no sense. Lots customers. Not sure if we will ever make the trip back because hey, ya never know if they will just be randomly closed on a Sunday afternoon!! Ugh. Did end up finding a great pizza place in downtown Mesa though. Queens Pizza and the waitstaff was awesome.

This restaurant offers a very unique experience with live music from an pipe organ.  The musician played a lot of popular kid songs to appease the children in the restaurant.  The pizza was decent and the pitcher of beer was cheap. Overall, the atmosphere was fun and quite memorable.  I definitely recommend it for families.

This place is always a great time. It's weird but very entertaining. I can't stop looking around at the massive organ when I eat here. The pizza is one of my favorites in town and I eat A LOT of pizza. They have good ice cream there as well.

I had a great time when I brought my mother, who came from out of town. The system was a bit confusing at first, but easy once you get it. They basically give you a number after you order your food, then you grab a seat somewhere, then wait until you see your number light up on a large scoreboard on the side of the building and get your order at the pickup area. It's not hard. The pepperoni pizza we ordered was hot, cheesy and tasty! A little pricey, but I think the price you pay is also for the show. The music was magical and fun and it was entertaining. I don't think it was any louder than music you'd hear at any bar tbh. Anyone who says differently may be over 70 or probably never frequent places with music playing overhead. You DO have to pay for refills but you can also buy pitchers which will save you some trips. We really enjoyed our time here and will be back again.

Organ Stop Pizza -- one of my favourite places to go when I'm in the Phoenix Metropolitan area.  First off, don't get me started with all the reviews about the pizza -- its average at best and yes, its expensive.  You don't come here for the food -- you come for the entertainment.  Watching the professionals that play that monster of a Wurlitzer Theatre Organ is what you're paying to see.  The best views and best sounds are on the 2nd floor -- there is no elevator, take the stairs to the left/right.  Also, the large wooden pipes in the back throw out some of the deepest bass I've ever heard and felt.  Its also funny to watch peoples hair literally get blown around by these pipes.    Again, the pizza isn't the attraction:  its just something nice to snack on while you listen to and watch this amazing machine.

Five star for the experience and the amazing organ player who apparently knows every song in the world by memory! Pizza is better than a Peter Piperish place, but that's definitely not why you go. The organ is amazing and the kids love it. The history of it is pretty cool too!

So la la.  Novelty for sure.  Pizza sucks hardcore.  Lot of old people.  Worthwhile seeing once but don't go out of your way unless you're a masochist.    It does get lined up, I'd recommend not being s total rookie and let the crowd thin, then. Reese in an hour after they open.  There'll still be plenty of seating.   Sucks for pictures, pretty dark.  Just go and enjoy and remember what I told you, expect the worst and hope for the best.

While the star at this place is not the pizza, it is definitely satisfactory.  However, the atmosphere is great, and the organs make this restaurant worth going to.  The organists are always fantastic, and they play requests throughout the meal.  Kids love watching the organs, so it provides a fun night of entertainment for any family.

Well we finally tried this Arizona landmark. Everything that you've heard is true. Food is mediocre, organ and room is entertaining. The building is all pipes! It resembles an Octoberfest Brewhaus, with a balcony, and long tables with seating in the round. You pay cash for your food and wait to see your number on a board. You then go pick it up and walk it upstairs. Not ideal but ok.   Food was blah. Organist and atmosphere was something we haven't seen before.   Every one at the table said, so we got this place outta the way. Meaning we've all been trying to experience it. We have. Now we can move on. It's hard to say if I'll go back.

The organist is both talented and humorous, playing a wide range of requested tunes like Frozen, the Big Band era, and patriotic numbers. The available sound effects, lighting (including a disco ball), and instrumentation is great. It entertained folks from age 3 to 80, which made it a great multi-generational night out.    Beyond the music, the pizza and salad bar aren't bad either. It can be slightly inconvenient to have the drinks paid for separately from the pizza, and in being cash only, but definitely enjoyable.

It's sooooo loud!!!  The kiddos loved it!  While my ears were ringing, we had a large salad from the salad bar and a medium combination pizza.  I added a small personal cheese and fried zucchini.  I would not call that a vegetable, but it was good.  My little cutie pie and nephew were dancing to the music while eating.  I told them that this would be the ONLY place they could do that.    I looked around and there were elderlies, young couples and small families enjoying the music entertainment.  It was a fun night!
Great Pizza, fabulous entertainment by a great musician. You have to see it to believe it.  Food is great. Pizza was crisp at the bottom and a great taste. It was non greasy.

Had a great time with my partners and their wives and their children.  The pizza and food is fairly good. Nothing spectacular here. Most come for the entertainment whish was wonderful. There is a huge organ as the centerpiece of the restaurant.  We had a wonderful time singing along to the tunes and the organ has so much going on it was a delight to just sit and watch as the oranist played.   I do wish they played longer sets however.  Service was 5/5. Fod wa 3/5.  Overall 4/5.
Just the best!!  Great pizza!  Great music!!!  Love this place!!!!  Have be going for more than 40 years to organ stop.  Place is packed be still fast and fun!!!!

Pizza was really good! Ordered the pepperoni and cheese pizza. I wasn't a fan of their beer options but this isn't a place for drinking. The entertainment was really good! Really good spot for families and older crowd.

I brought my family here from out of town and it was a very memorable evening. What I like most about this place is that there isn't another one like it anywhere in the world. Very very unique. Food is great and drinks are cheap. The entertainment is stellar and the atmosphere is welcoming. Definitely worth checking out!

Very fun, especially for little kids :) the guy playing the organ is great and takes requests which is very impressive. Love the song selection and the lights and bubbles. The pizza is ok, not the best, and remember to bring cash, they don't take cards, just cash out check.

They don't have any signs saying they only accept cash,  but they only accept cash.    So after you order,  you then have to walk over to the ATM "conveniently" located 20 feet from the register,   PAY A FEE,   bring the cash straight over to the cashier in plain view,  where the cashier will then spend 5 minutes scrutinizing the bills you JUST GOT FROM THEIR ATM to make sure they're not counterfeit.        I really hate... loathe this practice of deliberately shucking the cash fee onto the customer;  if we swiped at the register it might cost an extra half a percent or whatever Visa's fee is,  but because they do the stupid ATM game it's $2 + the $2.50 Wells Fargo charges for a non-WF ATM added on to my $35 crappy-pie-and-awful-beer dinner.     That sucks.     The pie itself is pretty expensive... well, I guess it comes with a unique show right?  Then you have to walk over to another counter to order drinks in a separate transaction,  and the drinks will be served in a crusty old cup that smells and tastes like dish soap.   The pizza itself is sub-mediocre.      The show,  while absolutely unique,  is too robotic and genericized to really be of much entertainment value... I know that not just anybody can play such an instrument so the few people who can & do are probably less than thrilled to have to put on the same show night after night,  and can't really be expected to insert thrills and magic into each and every performance - I say this without sarcasm, it's probably really not the most rewarding career on earth - but the result is kinda like going to chuck-e-cheese.     So, in summary,  Organ Stop Pizza is awful and I wish one of those business makeover shows would come fix the restaurant problems so it's possible to actually enjoy the amazing facility.
I have been coming to Organ Stop Pizza since I was a toddler. Great entertainment for adults and children. Pizza is delicious, and affordable. Great for large or small groups.

Organ Stop Pizza is an ATTRACTION that sells food. The food isn't the best just like from any other attraction but I do note they are very clean and post a Grade "A" Health Inspection Sign.  That said this is a very casual large family friendly place where you order at the counter, pay, get your drinks and silverware, seat yourself and look to a giant board on the wall for your number and pick up your food yourself.   The attraction is seeing and hearing one of the largest Wurlitzer Organs in the world. Not all but many of the songs played are theme songs. I heard the Star Wars Theme Song followed by the Star Trek Theme Song. I heard American Theme Songs and lots of Disney Theme Songs. Beware lots of young children all around dancing to the music between tables. Lots of family gatherings with birthday parties too.  Downstairs they have setting for about 500 people in bench style tables. It is very loud downstairs but you are closer to the organ can see more of the organ around the room.  Upstairs is smaller and seats around 200 people with tables. Upstairs might be the romantic spot because you are near the woofers and the seats vibrate a lot when the Titanic Theme Song is played.  The salad bar is similar to what budget steak houses offer but the difference is that everything was fresh.  The pizza is similar to a frozen pizza but slightly better. The crust is thin and crispy covered in corn meal or semolina and the cheese is better than from a frozen pizza.  Nobody waits on you but they do have bus people to clear the plates and clean.  For those that get board of the organ playing people can spend time in the arcade or shop for stuffed animals and organ playing music at the gift shop.  Parking is easy in the very large parking lot.  This place was fun and should be on everyone's bucket list!
Fun, unusual, unexpected treat in the desert.  Bring the kids.

My kids love it here! I've lived in the valley many years and only heard about this place recently. I'm surprised it never comes up in the things to do around town? They even have gluten free pizza. Check it out.

A large 1 topping pizza is $14.79 plus tax and is about the same quality as freezer pizzas. So why the 4 stars? The entertainment. What you are actually paying for is a pipe organ recital (in a fun way) with imaginative, fun lighting and animated characters. The noise level can be pretty intense here and indeed many families are not very good at supervising their obviously over-stimulated children. The lines can be quite long to order food, but they assign you a number which lights up on a large board so that you can return to the entertainment until your food is ready for pick up at the counter. A non-mall location (bonus points), easy parking, talented organists, and friendly staff. This place will delight your children and the inner child in you.
Very cool place to try at least once! Pizza is extremely good and loud fun atmosphere!

Fun place, very unique. Obviosly the main feature is the organist and the broad array of aspects of the organ. The organist was phenomenal and could play every request that was given to him. We couldnt believe how many different things he controlled with the gorgeous organ. The cat puppets were creepy.  Food: I would give the pizza a 6/10. The crust was a little crisp for my liking.   Seating: Sit up top in the middle. These seats get taken first and the sides have pillars that slightly block your view, not bad though.  Bring CASH ONLY! They don't take cards.

Despite spending many years growing up in Mesa, I was one of my few friends to not attend this particular neighborhood staple. Last night I visited with a social group that I belong to, and I have to say that it was everything I was worried it was gonna be.  The food was awful, the service was terrible, and the organ was so loud it made the one positive thing about this place an utter annoyance.  Our group was seated upstairs, which meant that we had to come up and down the stairs and carry our pizza, appetizers, drinks, pitchers of beer ourselves. This was a big turn off for me. After years of serving tables, I have no issue with it, but I watched several friends spill things.   The place was run down and desperately in need of a deep cleaning. Especially the filthy carpets.  When I ordered my Diet Pepsi, I was asked if I wanted it without caffeine or with? Instant reminder that I was in mesa. I don't recall stuttering, but I politely told him that I wanted regular Diet Pepsi. The employee had this incredible judgmental look on his face while serving me. Another thing I don't miss about living in Mesa.  AND NO FREE REFILLS ON SODA! What kind of ridiculous nickel and dime tactic is that? You have a soda fountain. Assuming you are using 5 gallon BIB's, even with free refills, your profit margin would still be insane.    When we came down to pick up our pizza and appetizer combo basket, the employee spilled the combo basket. No apologies, no compensation, just "I'll get a new one but it will be about 10 minutes"   By the time it was remade, we had finished our pizza, and we were done eating. After we tried a few pieces of what was clearly frozen appetizers off the back of a truck, we left them on the table for friends to pick at.  The pizza was horrible. Toppings, cheese, and sauce were ok, but the crust reminded me of one of those disgusting Totinos frozen pizzas. Not worth the 20 bucks they charged. I've had better pizza from Little Caesars. Which isn't saying a hell of a lot.  The organist was very talented, but frankly, it's just too damn loud in there. While the music is playing, you can't converse with anyone in your party without shouting at the top of your lungs. Not to mention that the song selection was so family friendly it was nauseating. AMAZING GRACE isn't exactly the most uplifting dinner song when all it's ever been used for is funerals and launching vulcans into deep space.  Long story short... I'm glad I experienced it, so that I might warn others. I will not be returning.  If you go, go for the music and consider the crappy food, and service a cover charge.

Make certain you arrive as soon as they open. Check their website for what time they will open. It differs between seasons/ weekends/week days. If you wait til later in the day, the restaurant will Be packed and you will have a difficult time finding a seat. Eat VERY slow and enjoy the music. Organ player begins playing 30 min after they open and he takes requests. Place your order than find a seat while you watch for your number. Drinks and ice cream are paid separately. When your number is posted go back to the counter to pick up your order. We sat upstairs, chairs were comfortable. Downstairs seating is on picnic style benches. Pizzas are absolutely Delicious !!!!! They also offer spaghetti and hot sandwiches. The organist plays for 30 min. Than takes a 15 min break. Plan on eating slow and staying awhile, it's well worth the stay. Relax and enjoy . Oh yes they also have a salad bar with a pretty Good selection.
Brought my family here from Minnesota. It was a fun outing- dinner and a show. We really liked the PSM pizza and zucchini sticks.

You don't come for the run-of-the-mill pizza. Nor do you show up for the cheap pitchers of beer. No, you make it here for the show. A massive organ fills the entire building, incorporating dozens of intruments, and the virtuosos playing it take center stage. Sit back and watch then perform your favorite songs, from Star Wars to The Little Mermaid. Don't let the average food dissuade you from a one-of-a-kind experience.

This place was amazing!  When you walk in, it looks like a Chuck E. Cheese minus the skiball.  Their menu is pretty simple, and you pay for things separately (cash only).  Service was great! The food is alright.  But honestly, you don't go here for the food.    I don't go out of my way to listen to organ music.  But this guy was great!  And it was mesmerizing.  He played standards, Disney, and even played bohemian rhapsody on this thing.  It was awesome!   Each time we thought we would leave, he'd play something crazy like Thriller and we'd get sucked back in.  I bet Christmas music is bomb!   This is something to experience.  Get a pizza, enjoy it.  There really is nothing like it.

We've been to this place several times over the years. As a matter of fact, our family celebrated my daughter's second and fifth birthdays here (we did not have a "party" - so I'm not sure how that works - we just brought our own cake and had dinner here).   Anyone complaining about the pizza is missing the point. We don't come here to have a culinary experience; we come for the show (although the pizza is not bad. It's not great. It's exactly what you think it will taste like while you are reading this review. It's pizza, and you will probably like it unless you are really picky). I like the pizza, I love the fried mushrooms and... well, that's what we always get. We talk about getting dessert but then we fill up on that (good) pizza.   But the real reason to come is the ambiance, and of course the music. The organists know how to play songs that everyone can recognize and there is something for everyone to get excited about (the theme songs from Indiana Jones, Ghostbusters,and Star Wars, Thriller, Bohemian Rhapsody, etc.) Not only does the beautiful organ emerge from middle of a stage (and descend back into the stage during intermissions); there is movement on the walls from various instruments, and a little light show happening at the same time. My favorite part is when a curtain opens over a little alcove where four cat puppets dance. Kids love this place. Old people love this place. (They really do. Bring your grandma; she will love this place). And I love this place. It's been around for over 40 years, so most locals have been to it or at least heard of it. It's definitely worth checking out whether you live here or are passing through.

Organ Stop has been a favorite for years.  Not very close, the playfulness of the place make the trip so worth it.  The pizza is almost the best on the planet.  The crew are friendly and eager to help. The 2 organists are top flight and if you want, their CD's can be bought. The queue can be horrendous even just a little after opening so get there early or a couple hours after they open - after usual dinner time. But the quality of the food it worth it!!

After driving out to Mesa from Phoenix, we found this place to be HUGE,  with about a three acre parking lot...totally jammed...Inside there was a long line and the dining room , on two floors was packed to the rafters.  We would have had to wander around for a week to get a table. The organ is pretty impressive, and the music was nifty, but the crowd and the chaos were not so nifty.   They do not take credit cards- is there ANY restaurant that does not take plastic  any more?- only cash or checks (!).   They had an ATM but I was afraid to see how much they charged for cash.  The prices seemed  OK, but the pizza didn't look all that wonderful- I guess they're selling the organ music.  The clientele was young couples with kids- noisy ones- and old snowbirds from Canada.  The ambiance was part Vegas early-bird senior buffet and part Cub Scout Jamboree, unsupervised.  There's no service.  You order at the desk and come back and get it when it is done.   I dunno- maybe you like that sort of thing.  Ain't my cup o' tea.  Maybe a return visit on a Tuesday in July.
They have gluten free pizza too. There is a great salad bar. The organ music is fun and excellent. I'll be back.  News article ABC15 http://youtu.be/7Mtr-Bi8liE  Check YouTube for more videos.
Good food. Organ is great and you can put in requests of your favorite songs. Like star wars or phantom of the opra

Organ Stop Pizza - A Favorite for Young & Old Alike!  While I am not the biggest fan of Organ Stop, I do find it somewhat entertaining.  It is always fun to watch the young ones sing along and dance to the music!  However, many times it's the Seniors that have the most fun!  I am not sure why, but Senior Citizens love this place (so you might not want to come early)!  I honestly think they shuttle seniors in, there are that many...  The pizza is okay, though I like pretty much all pizza!  If you are in the area, or have kids or grandparents, give it a try!  Cheers!
What a great time!! Pizza is delicious and salad bar!! We love listening to the organ! We could spend hours here. BRING CASH OR CHECK! They do not accept cards.

One word: Kitsche. I was looking for a fun dinner "experience" to treat my daughter to. This place comes up in every family dining guide and I guess it's because only kids under 7 would not be completely horrified by this place.   First of all - cash only. You stand in line to order. The food is overpriced and very sub-par. You have to cram yourself in on a bench next to strangers (unless you have a group big enough to take up the whole table - maybe 6-10people?). You will probably lose your seat if you need to get up and order another drink or use the restroom.   The organ plays... Interesting... Pieces of music. It *is* cool to see how different parts of the room sync with the organ/music as it plays. However it was not worth the overall experience of being smushed next to strangers, overpaying and eating bad food.   I will admit - my daughter was enthralled by the "finale" song of each set - where they blow bubbles and the disco ball comes out and it's like a 2minute party in the room. But again... Not worth it. It's 2 min of smiles and 60min of torture.

I had a hot date last Saturday night at the Organ Stop... and it definitely ended on a high note (pun intended).  Of course, my "date" was my 3 yr old son and the night ended at 6:30pm with strawberry ice cream - but if that's the kind of night you're looking for then the Organ Stop won't disappoint :)  We arrived at 4:45 to beat the rush but I didn't anticipate the senior citizen rush that had started at 4:30, so it was crowded.  We waited about 10 min in line for food but I was prepared with my order and cash so it went smoothly enough.  The dining room was PACKED no lie.  There were a few open tables but only in corners upstairs where you couldn't see the organist, so what would be the point?  We finally found 3 people sitting at an 8 person table near the stage who were nice enough to share with my son and me.  Honestly, all the people there seemed really nice; they were mostly older and smiled and laughed at my son when he was being his exuberant self during the music.  I was pretty astonished at how well he behaved.  It took about 20 min after we sat down for our food to be ready - small pizza, basket of fried zucchini, mushrooms, and mozzarella, and small salad.  I thought the food was good, not amazing but better than some of the other posters made it sound.  The salad bar was very basic and definitely the low point of our meal, but at $2.99 not a huge deal.  My son enjoyed his pizza, so if he eats - I'm happy.  The organist was fantastic!  Some of the songs he played were that Dancing Cats song with the puppets (my son was mesmerized), theme from Star Wars (my fave), A Wonderful World, some kind of Choo Choo train song, Abba, etc.  There was also a set of patriotic songs played for soldiers in the audience which I thought was cool.  In summary, it was a fun place to take my son for dinner.  Everyone was friendly, the beer was cheap (yes, I had a pint, shhh) , and my kid was entertained long enough for me to actually finish my own dinner before telling me he wanted to leave.  I will be taking him again for sure!

This was our second time there. The first was during regular hours, this time during special group hours. The performance on the huge theater organ was excellent both times, and is fun for all. The pizza is adequate.

I went to Organ Stop for the first time this year and enjoyed it.  Not the food!  The food is terrible, except for the cheap ice cream.  But the show was pretty neat, and he took requests.  Where else can you hear Smooth Criminal, a Star Wars medley, and Disney songs like "Let It Go" from Frozen all done on an organ with animated props while you dine?  My kids and husband enjoyed it for about the first 10 minutes, but were begging to leave as soon as they were done eating.  LOL.  I could have stayed for another round of tunes.  I'd certainly go back if we had visitors in town who wanted to see the spectacle.  Note: Cash only.  And it's really loud during the show.  Neat show + cheap ice cream = 3 stars.

So I did a search for top punk/indie bars in Mesa, and to my surprise, this was rated #13 above Cobra Arcade Bar. So out of curiosity, I took an Uber there from Cornish Pasty Co. I was kinda shocked to see a line going around the building, with people dressed for what appeared to be a punk show.   For the life of me, I was so confused. But my curiosity got the best of me, and I stuck around - one of the best shows I've ever been to. They setup a stage in front of the iconic organ, and the band was none other than The Copyrights and Something Fierce. The show was insane - all the benches and tables were pushed to the side of the room, and they started a pit where someone would normally be eating their pizza.  Such a perfect punk venue - hidden in plain sight behind the organ and the flags draped over the window. Noise ordinance be damned - this place in Mesa kicked ass.

This isn't a place I'd go to on a regular basis unless I had out-of-town guests.  So lately I have been going on a regular basis.  It's a really fun place to take guests, and a much bigger deal than one would think from descriptions of the establishment.    Organ Stop Pizza all about the show, not the pizza.  The 2-level eating area is quite  big, surrounding a tall stage on three sides.  When the show starts, all of a sudden a beautiful and ornate organ with a musician rises in a slow spiral from the stage. The musician is incredible, not only playing a 40 minute set of show tunes, but also managing all of the buttons and plugs to operate numerous instruments around the ceiling, along with dancing cats and a quacking duck. During this time the background and various pipes, seen through plexiglass, change colors.    Organ Stop doesn't open until 4:00, so there's often a line waiting to get in.  No worries; it goes very fast.  Some people love the pizza, others not so much.  There is a nice salad bar.  Drinks are cheapest when ordered by the pitcher, and this includes beer and soft drinks.  There are no free refills.  Ice cream is also sold.  After an intermission, the second set of music may involve patriotic songs or singalongs -- whatever the talented musician feels like playing that night. Anniversaries and birthdays are recognized. It's a lot of fun for every age.
They don't have places like this back home! The entertainment was great. If you're looking for a quick sit down meal, this is a good place to go with the whole family. I'm glad we stopped here.

I finally got to go to this place after dating my now wife.  The organ is huge!  Not sure if it s the WOrlds Largest organ.  Try the Organ at the Conference Center in Salt Lake CIty Utah.  lol  The food was good but not great.  The pizza was tasty  but a little too much cheese for me.  It is dark and you cant see the people you are sitting with as good but that s part of the atmoshpere I guess.  The organ music is loud and they play some fun tunes.  I can see where it does get repetitive.

This place is a complete joke.. only take cash or check... really?? Gotta order your drinks seperate and paid for separately   from your food .. no place to sit... employees are rude and not helpful with questions ...I live here in Az and brought my guests here to eat but will definetly not be back ever again nor will I be bringing out of town guests either!!

1st off, the organ is incredible! It even held my teenagers attention, which is a hard task to accomplish.  The first of a couple issues are you have to pay with cash only.  If you don't have cash to pay, there is am ATM inside, that has a hefty fee. Then, after standing in line to order food, you are sent to a whole other line to stand in again... to order a soda/beer or beverage of your choice. And, you guessed it, pay cash again.  The tables are family style, so be ready to feel a bump from who sits behind you, and remember that drink? You get 1, which will go fast after having to yell to talk to your neighbors as it is very loud. The pizza is tasty, so that helps, but your on your own to order, keep track when it is ready, and go pick it up yourself as no one will help you. Good luck.

This place is great, mostly because of the organ, music, and friendly service. This is why I am giving 3 stars instead of 2. The music selection varies significantly ranging from songs that a appeal to children (Let It Go from Frozen) to songs older adults such as that from Sound of Music. The organ itself is grand, and the numerous other musical instruments add to the value of the show.  It is also a great place for casual family dining. There isn't a wait staff but there is staff to clear the tables once done.  However, let it be known that this restaurant's food is mediocre and the establishment itself could improve. The set-up to order food is also quite strange: you order and pay for food in one line and then go to a separate line to pay for drinks. It is also cash only which is an inconvenience for me since I rarely ever carry cash. As for the food, we ordered the pizza. It wasn't terrible, but I wouldn't come back for it. The building itself looks and smells old and outdated.
Pretty cool pizza place. Food is good, but definitely not the best pizza I've had. The organ show is incredible though, and definitely worth the visit! Also this place is cash only!

When we arrived, my husband was a little discouraged by the number of elderly people that were waiting in line to get in.  But after our experience we realized this is a great place for a break in the monotony of multi-generational family dinners.    The pizza earns 2-3 stars from me.  I'm more of a Pizza Bianco/Humble Pie/La Bocca kind of girl.  Not a big fan of the doughy, over-cheesed kind of pizza.  But, that's what they have here, so that's what we ate.  Really nothing special, but not horrible either.  Their salad bar is pretty standard; also nothing special.  We didn't try any of their sandwiches or specialty dishes.  However, the entertainment was unlike anything I've ever seen before, and we all really enjoyed it.  The organ pipes are quite a spectacle: a countless number of them, two stories high, all throughout the dining hall.  There are drums and bongos on the walls and bells and xylophones hanging from the ceiling.  The organ itself rotates on a platform at the front and center of the dining hall.  I bet your organ doesn't do that.  (On that note, I'll inform you that the "giant organ" and "huge pipes" lend themselves to a number of inappropriate jokes.  So, have fun with that!)  Being the holiday season, we heard a lot of Christmas music both familiar and unfamiliar.  My stepdaughter was elated when they played her current theme song, "All I want for Christmas is My Two Front Teeth."  And all of the kids loved the "It's a Small World/Mickey Mouse Club" theme song medley with the banner of Mickey hanging from the ceiling and "Under the Sea" with blue lights on the disco ball and bubbles at the end.  Personally, I was a fan of the Phantom of the Opera medley.    The organist has a request box at the front of the stage that he checks every so often and he recognizes birthdays and special occasions and plays songs for them.    We're looking forward to doing another family dinner here sometime. Between grandma, adult kids and grandkids (ages 1-7), our gang had a really good time here!

Warning....the food is not good. Peter piper pizza is better and that's not saying much. That being said, you don't come here for pizza. It's all about the nostalgic organ music. It's a great time with friends and family. They only take cash, so pull some out before you come. Check the website. Often times, there are deals that are going on. You definitely have to come check it out if you live close by.

WAIT! STOP! Do NOT go here for the Pizza!  Will it kill you? I think your life is more at risk by walking through the parking lot during the snowbird season. The pizza is passable, but you do not go to Organ stop for the pizza.  To enjoy Organ Stop, you must be a music lover. I mean the band geek variety. I was lucky enough to get my father here before he passed away, and every time I go since I reminisce in his enjoyment, in my parents enjoyment of a wide variety of music.  For the uninitiated, the location at 1149 East Southern Avenue in Mesa is built to house a Wurlitzer Organ (OK Mike, try, try to avoid the huge organ jokes) with over 6,000 pipes. Additionally, percussive and horn instruments are tied to the instrument, not to mention the dancing cats, singing birds, disco ball and bubble machines. Keep in mind, one person operates this thing. I know they do have the ability to sample and replay the different overlays, but it's still very impressive stuff. I've seen three or four musicians in my many visits, my personal favorite in Charlie Balough.  The crowd varies between kiddie and senior, and can be especially senior during snowbird season. After it warms up a bit, it's much easier to get in, sit down, eat mediocre pizza and drink a pitcher of beer while you list to an artist play a wide assortment of musical selections.   I've been there many, many times, and it's a consistent experience. Enjoy yourself and teach your kids to appreciate music.

Organ Stop Pizza is unique. The obvious big draw to this place is the massive organ and the very talented organist. Truly impressive and charming. While we were there he played several songs, all from different genres. My very busy bodied 7-year-old was very entertained.   When you first enter the restaurant you go up to the counter to order. We ordered a simple pizza with pepperoni, sausage, and mushrooms. We also ordered a "small salad" which is salad bar style, but there are several signs up that ask that you only take one trip to the salad bar. Lame. And again, seems like cheap skate business to me. Then when we went to pay, found out that they take CASH ONLY -No debit or credit cards. This is such a pet peeve of mine. It is 2014. Who carries cash anymore?! Add $0.05 to each item to cover the costs of having a credit card machine and call it good. Quit being ridiculous! They do have an ATM in the restaurant so, we quickly got cash out and then went to order our drinks....which are down the side of the counter and you pay separately for as well.  Again, annoying. Why are the multiple stations necessary??   The dinning area is seat yourself and we found a nice little spot in the corner. It was very busy but we could still see pretty well. You are given a number on your receipt and the numbers go up on a big board in the dinning area, similar to a bingo board. Our pizza was ready pretty quickly but, the food was mediocre, at best, and very overpriced for what we got. For the large pizza, two small salads, and two sodas- it was just over $40. For a dinner out, that is pretty typical for that kind of order but, again- I was annoyed by the lack of service and inconveniences, and when I go out to eat, I want the food to be fantastic...this wasn't.  I would however, highly recommend checking this place out AFTER having dinner somewhere else. Then get some cash out, come in, get some drinks and enjoy the organ for a few hours.

Stay with me, this might get confusing for ya, my daughter (3rd oldest) was in town for the weekend for a visit and my other daughter (2nd oldest) said we should go somewhere where it doesn't matter how loud the kids get, where it's fun and entertains them and allow us to visit and for others to join us, I told her I had my fill of Peter Piper Pizza for the year not going there, she said Mom lets go to Organ Stop Pizza, I laughed, no really I laughed, Organ Stop has never been on my list of places to go and its sort of a running joke on YT,  my daughter then told me that she has been before and my grandson loves it.  Come to find out, most of my kids (have 4 total and not so much on the kid side anymore ranging frm 22 to 17) have been to Organ Stop and do enjoy it. (I fully believe they live a secret life when my eyes were closed, I thought they were out running the streets, but nope it was hanging out at Organ Stop haha) So Organ Stop Pizza was the place picked, time to meet up was a Friday night at 6:30pm. Off we went  We got there a little before 6:30 because wanted to make sure to get tables and set up for everyone, and damn the parking lot is FULL, Yep I was shocked! Didn't know it was such a hot spot to go to.  Prior to coming my (2nd oldest) daughter told me to find tables on the 1st floor (1st floor??? WTH this is a pizza joint right??? 2 floors?) And after walking in I saw what she meant. When you 1st walk in you are facing the menu board to order pizza, I'll get back to that, but if you go to your right you will see the dining room, and low and behold it has 2 floors of seating. 1st floor was completely filled up, so I went upstairs and found us 2 long tables.  Then I stopped and really looked around. 1st observation, DAMN THAT'S A HUGE ORGAN, and not so much a HUGE ORGAN, it's the pipes, they are in the walls, and all over, is this a sound proof building? Can you hear it on the street??  2nd, this must have been an old church, that's the feeling it gives from the 2 floors and seating arrangements.   I have to say hearing scores of the Phantom of the Opera played on that bad ass organ sounded amazing and the light show that went with it, I liked it.   Ok like I said when you 1st walk in you are faced with ordering your pizza. This is where the place loses points, it's all scattered. In one place you order your pizza and pay for it, then get into another line, order your salad and pay for it, then get into another line for drinks and pay for it.  Why can't it be one stop shopping experience?  Oh and everything is CASH ONLY.  I ordered 1 large Hawaiian, 1 Large Combination, 1 medium Spicy Italian for 54 bucks, then ordered 3 pitchers of soda (MT Dew, Root beer, Sierra Mist) for 15 bucks. I tried the Hawaiian & Combination, the Hawaiian had chopped ham throughout the pizza and good amount of pineapple, the combo pizza wasn't lacking the bell peppers, for that's all I remember from it, but the pizza itself was not that great, it's like Little Creasers pizza but with a car dealership sticker price.   Do I feel like I got my money's worth? No not really, but what I did get was a meal with all 4 of my kids, 3 of my grandkids, tons of family and friends, some laughter and smiles, and that right there is what counts.   Return factor though is really low.

First time here. I must say this was such a fun place to eat and enjoy some awesome music. The pizza I ordered was huge and delicious! Def a family environment or if you have company in town and want to take them to a fun restaurant. The organ player was awesome and he played so many songs without sheet music.

This was our first time here. It was worth the 28 minutes to get here. The food was ok. Very much like a grownup Chuck e Cheese. You order your food and drinks at the counter. Decor has not changed since the 80s. The arcade was very old and run down. Lots of families and older folks. I've lived here my whole life! How did I not know about this place. So kitschy and fun! The organist is incredibly talented. My 4 year old thought the music was too loud. I would come back here!

I have seen this place for many years and never really knew what it was until a friend suggested we go there for dinner with the kids. I reluctantly agreed, as I didn't think it would be anything my kids would be interested in.  GOOD: Awesome set up with the organ and all the musical equiptment. The organ player was excellent and very personable. The disco ball and bubbles that they blow during certain songs was a nice touch.  BAD: The line to get in was rediculiously long. They only accept cash. You have to pay for your drinks seperately. There was nowhere to sit. The prices are way to high. The pizza tastes like microwave pizza. The food took forever and they weren't very clear when you ordered how to know when it's ready... they hand you a number and tell you to wait. The numbers go in no particular order so you have to pay attention. Half the games in the game room were out of order and took your money.  All in all it was an experience that I am glad I had but not glad enough to go again. Oh and my kids couldn't have cared less about the organ, just as I suspected.

Went here with a bunch of friends and family, never saw an organ that large attached to other playing music instruments...pretty neat. The food was mediocre, ordered a couple of pizzas(it was so so), fried mushrooms, fried zucchini and onion rings. Nothing really to crave about, good spot to go to for first time visitors.

This was our first time coming here and we did so for a friend's birthday party. I am giving this four stars because the experience was fun and unique. The music would play for awhile at a time which is fine just not what your used to I guess when you are accustom to talking with your party. The food was as expected upon arriving there and seeing the photos online. It makes sense with how this is a family establishment and pack a lot of ppl in there. It was good for Peter Piper like pizza but I am a food snob so I want better but as I am putting four stars I did not really have a complaint.
A fantastic place to take the family.  A unique opportunity that takes you back in time.  It is must for the family.
First time here.  The entertainment is wonderful, well worth seeing.  The pizza is good.  I would go back.

Organ Stop is a fun family friendly pizza place. There is a lot of seating however you do need to get there early. They open at 4. We got there around 4:30 and the only table available was in the very front to the far left which isn't the best viewing area (probably why that was the table left).   The food is probably 3 stars, the pizza was just okay and the salad bar is small but nice. It does cost over $3 for a small one trip plate. These are defiantly small plates, I am not a huge salad water but it was very difficult to fit much of anything on the plate.   I do not know if I like that the drinks are separate from the food ordering. I'm sure it cuts down on the time spent in line ordering drinks, but then you are waiting in a second line, almost equally as long waiting to order your drinks. If you have multiple people with you, I suggest agreeing on one type of pop and getting a pitcher, much cheaper that way.   I bumped this up a star from the food for the entertainment. The man playing the organ was great, very entertaining. Even had my 2 year old on his feet giving standing ovations (even when he wasn't feeling good).

Charlie Balogh might be the most talented musician ive seen in years.. he is truly amazing and really blew me away with each song he played. Should be on Broadway!! Oh and the zucchin sticks here and mushrooms were yummy as heck!!
What a great time!  Talented musicians, great entertainment, fun for any age, and I mean ANY age.  Good food and nice people!
I thought the pizza was really tasty, and the Wurtlitzer (and the organist) was amazing. Such a fun experience!

Come for the music, stay for the pizza.  I guess I'm in the minority, but I really like their pizza. Their cooking system yields a very crispy layer on the bottom of an otherwise fluffy crust as opposed to some pizzas that have a more soggy, chewy crust.  I also ordered the combo appetizer, fried mushrooms, zucchini, and mozzarella sticks. Loved the mushrooms and zucchini.  The CASH ONLY policy might be a problem if you aren't prepared.  As for the music... It is loud and I think there's a canned set list (with a few requests thrown in, I asked for "Toccata and Fugue in D Minor" and he played it straight (no embellishments). Alas it totally killed the festive mood in the room. Sorry. I enjoyed it.  It's not a place I'd go to frequently, but I'd return occasionally for the pizza and zucchini and see if he'd take my odd requests. I see in another review that he did "Stairway to Heaven." I wonder if he would do "Bohemian Rhapsody?"

Having grown up in Mesa, I've been here many, many times. The last time I was here was 15 years ago when I was in high school. Tonight I brought my husband and kids.  The place literally has not changed in all these years. It's crazy! Like a time capsule! These lose a star for me because of their totally antiquated POS system (ok it's not even that, it's a manual old school cash register). It's CASH ONLY. I mean seriously? Also, you have order your pizza in one line and get your drinks in another line, and pay separately. It makes absolutely no sense!  They also lose a star because the pizza is terrible. I mean just awful.  Ok now that the gripes are out of the way...we had a blast! My kids were all smiles, laughing and dancing the whole time. They were fascinated the the huge organ and all the bells and whistles. The dancing cats, the bubbles, the lights! The kids LOVED it! The organist was really good. He played a stunning version of Phantom of the Opera that I loved.  We got the kids ice cream which was only $2 each. Not bad.  Bottom line the entertainment is great, the venue is very casual and super family friendly. It's a great time with the fam. But maybe I'll just get a salad next time.

Fun experience for kids and pretty cool to see for the musically-inclined (if not but for the first 10-15 mins or so).  The pizza was average - on par w/Chuck E Cheese - and the penny pinching was more than obvious.  They charge way more than expected to add a salad bar to your order and strictly allow one visit - it's sort of like a grumpy cafeteria lady is running shop or something.    I will say the organist and the instrument is impressive.  But seriously - the arcade is embarrassing and stole like half of my kids quarters on non-functional old arcade games ($1.00 to play a game that's probably 20 years old now?  Really!  $.50 for Cruisin USA!  Like a bad joke that sucks in 5 year olds).

Stopped here for dinner on a Monday night with my cousin and boyfriend before flying out of Phoenix.   We shared a large combination pizza, onion ring app, and a pitcher of Miller (pitcher was only ~$7!). Food was okay, but the star was the live organ playing. It was so impressive I cannot even begin to fully describe it. The organ pipes and everything took up an entire wall of the place, with additional sound/visual effects lining the ceiling and interior. It was so cool listening to Phantom of the Opera, Mamma Mia, etc.  The crowd was mainly older folks and families with children. Although there are signs that tell parents to make sure their children don't run around everywhere, many parents seemed to ignore that. Children were running everywhere, up and down stairs, and screaming. This was the only thing that detracted from our experience.  Otherwise, this was definitely a very cool, unique place to go to. If my parents ever go to Phoenix, I would recommend them stopping by this place!

This place gets suuuuper busy around dinner time, but it made it really enjoyable to eat here at the same time!  I do wish they had some line control at the entrance though; you had a very long line out the door to order (to go?), and another side where people were exiting, and another of people trying to go in to find a table to sit at... it was a huge cluster---- around the doors!  But once you're inside it really opens up, the entire building is one giant organ - every instrument you see on the wall is used when a song is being played! It gets pretty loud in here, and I did find myself shouting a bit over the crowd noise, but overall I didn't find it annoying, just part of the fun :)  The pizza was SO good, crispy underside, yummy mozzarella cheese... I'm literally drooling thinking about this pizza again!! Unfortunately I didn't get the chance to try their ice cream, but next time for sure I will!  I would highly suggest sending a family member into the building to save a table spot while the other orders if it's your first time here because it can get pretty hectic in there! I love sitting on the second level because you get a really good overview of the organist and the instruments working.

I love Organ stop pizza, just not for the PIZZA. You have to visit at least once to see the organist and the pipes and instruments playing. Organ stop boasts the world's largest Wurlitzer Organ, and its spectacular presence is worth the trip alone.   It's a great place to take out of towners! It also appears to be a great place to take young and old and has a birthday party atmosphere. The food could be better! We tried the pizza twice and it's just ok.  They take song requests and they do their best to play a variety of songs. Worth a first and second visit! They do have salad and ice cream as well but bring cash or checks because they do not take credit cards. Also check the hours before you go because they are not open all day.

Came here once for the experience and will never come back. It was cool but like, so divey and gross and you're not even getting quality food or service so once was enough for me. Cash only. Pizza is very mediocre. I'd rather eat dominoes or even a frozen digiorno. Drinks are separate and no free refills and no Coke products. Ha sorry I'm a Coke girl!!!!! Fun place for kids I guess. The organ is the only cool thing about it. Really fun to watch. It's loud too FYI.

Organ Stop Pizza is a must for those who have never been, and for those visiting from out of town. You don't need me to tell you that, since you will undoubtedly be smacked in the face with elderly folks and oxygen tanks. Sometimes even tour buses full drop off. I suggest off-season visits. Parking can be atrocious,  bit at least it's free.  The vintage organ is visible both from the exterior and interior. The organist rises from the floor in a spectacular display. He takes requests and passes birthday, anniversary and other special messages. It really is a sight. Be prepared that it is really loud. Don't expect any semblance of conversation here. If I put my mouth directly near you ear,  I bet you couldn't hear me.  The pizza and accoutrement is substandard. This is about the organ and the novelty really, with a side of pizza. The young counter staff is mostly disinterested. Ordering is weird because pizza is separate from drinks, which is separate from ice cream. Really kind of a poorly thought out set up. Also be aware that when your order is ready, the light flashes your number on a Keno-style board on each side of the room, toward the balcony area. They don't explain it, so people get confused.  If you get weirded out by picnic table, family-style seating, know that this is what seating is here. At times it is really hard to find a table, even on the upper balcony. Have family find a table before you get the food to alleviate some seat - finding stress. The tables have been varnished a million and a half times,  so combined with the food residue,  it's always sticky.  But that said, even if you are a local and have never been, it is a spectacle that you must see at least once. Strike that. Not AT LEAST ONCE,  ONLY ONCE. It's a one and done. Trust me.

This is probably the best place to go! It's so fun and exciting! Best for birthday parties and anniversary's! The organ and music is my favorite part of going here! It's so amazing and fantastic.   This is definitely a must! They have really good fresh pizza and salads!   Personally, music is my favorite in the world and this place makes me happy! Great job Organ Stop Pizza!

This is a great place for the family! I love that they take music requests as you eat. The puppets, drums, and lights add to the organ experience! Wish it was a little less crowded and more organized (perhaps reservations).

This is such a fun place! Up front: CASH ONLY & You don't just come looking for good pizza, that's not really the point of it as stated in other reviews. It's for the amazing organ and music you'll be entertained by as you eat. World famous organist come here to play for you and it does not disappoint, the organ is basically the entire building, there are pipes EVERYWHERE! It's gorgeous, it blew my mind. I've never been somewhere like this before. Bubbles came from the ceiling when the organist played the little mermaid!! Great spot for birthday parties no matter what the age, and the pizza isn't bad, it was actually pretty good! It's not gourmet, and the vibe when you walk in is almost Chuck E. Cheese but once you get to the seating area (it's family style, long tables take a seat!) that completely changes and you're focused on who is playing the organ. Lights around the room change colors to the songs! So glad my boyfriend brought me here, we will be coming back!

Reminds me of the Organ Grinder Pizza that used to be in Portland, OR. Food is good, Pizza and appetizers.  Service is pretty fast because when we were there they were pumping through masses of people.  The entertainment, if you like Organ playing is tremendous the organist is very talented.  An enjoyable dinner evening for the family!

Unique experience you won't forget!  If you're coming here for the pizza alone, don't.  If you're coming for a fun time, then come. The organists are very talented, and fun to watch.  We got the small salad bar and it was plenty, with the pizza. Not sure if I would return, but for a one and done fun time for the kids, you can't beat it.

Music is fun, played Gonna Fly Now from Rocky perfectly for my sons birthday. The pizza is average Arizona fast food pizza, not good not bad definitely worth checking this place out for its originality.

I feel like Organ Stop is a place you come to to enjoy the organ, not so much the pizza. (I don't write bad reviews, so I'll keep it about the organ.) The organist plays a variety of tunes! There is a request jar near him and most of the time he plays all of the songs! It's fun trying to guess the songs and looking around to see all the little instruments on the walls move.
Way cool!!! Not just your normal pizza place!! The pizza is awesome but the organ is over the top!! This is a must stop if your in the state of Arizona!!

The music is so cool! The organ players take requests which is especially nice for birthdays. The organ pipes surround the whole dining room which is two levels. With special songs they even release bubbles like with "under the sea". This is a great place to take kids! Pizzas are pretty good but nothing too special. They also have beer and a salad bar. Oh and take cash because they don't accept cards!

Phenomenal music! It's similar to attending a live concert (with only one human). He an amazing genius.  Pizza is pretty good and fantastic atmosphere.   Downside: The sub sandwich did not meet my expectation (small), and there are no drink refills besides coffee. And cash only (bring at least $15/person).   Have to come here at least once.

I've always enjoyed this place. We haven't been in over a decade. When we came, the place felt updated, unlike some other entertainment eatery's. The LED upgrade is The pizza has an airy feel to where you can devour the first slice and move on to another slice with ease!, LOL! The ordering process is really cool too. You order the pizza in one area and the beverages in another.

The pizza is okay but I go there for the ATMOSPHERE!!! I have been going here since I was little!! They only take cash but they do have an ATM. There is also a game room and instruments all over that the Organ plays! We love the songs that use the cat puppets.

Organ Stop Pizza is truly a family oriented establishment.  Long, large tables end-to-end everywhere, and (2) stories to boot.  The pizza was better than expected - traditional, not greasy, plenty of toppings built out so that there isn't even a bone.  Our group which had ages 1-60+, didn't have a single complaint and we had over (10) pies served of varying types.  Above all else, the music is great.  I've never experienced anything like this, and if you enjoy good wholesome family fun, I highly recommend Organ Stop Pizza.

If you've read any of these reviews, I'm sure you see the recurring theme- you come here for the experience...certainly not for the food or service.  One star for the organ- it's truly a thing of beauty. You should wander upstairs while you're there so you can get the full effect. The second star is for the the people who play the organ. They are EXTREMELY talented. When I watch them play, I'm totally in awe.  Sadly, two stars is the highest I can rate Organ Stop. This is a great place to take out of town guests, kids, or winter visitors. Just don't expect to be wow'ed by anything other than the music. Pizza is not so great, service is just ok, and cash only? Seriously? Plus the way you order is a mess. I wish Organ Stop would make a few updates to make the experience better but since they can make loads of money without changing a thing, I won't hold my breath.

I've been coming to Organ Stop Pizza since I was a kid with my family. The organ music and atmosphere are unique and enjoyable, and I love coming now for those reasons...but the food....not so great. The pizza isn't anything special, not much better than a $5 frozen pizza, and the salad bar is lacking. If they stepped it up on the quality of the food I would probably eat here more often. 2 stars for the awesome entertainment.

Went to the Phoenix one as a kid. This one doesn't disappoint.... super busy even on a weeknight....the organ seems like it tripled in size! The organ player took time after to tell us how it worked and the specifications ....it moves 55,000 cubic feet of air per minute.......Food was good and prices were very affordable... coming back for sure since the kids were amazed for hours.
This is the best restaurant/entertainment venue in the United States. I can't explain it to you, you'll just have to check it out for yourself.

Five stars for the memory. (hope you all enjoy it) When I was a kid we went here as a family all the time, but one time when I was a baby the organ came out and started playing and I almost bit my moms boob (other parts but keeping this pg for the kids) right off. No matter how many times we go back, nothing will ever get my family to stop telling that story. Lol.  Pizza is decent, and service has always been ok, although I haven't been there in quite some time!

Very cute place to take your family. Naturally the world's largest Wurlitzer is the main attraction and it definitely entertains. I've never seen a theater organ that controls so many different instruments. It's quite a show. Definitely suggest to do at least once in your life. It's a totally unique experience. The food is nothing to rave about, but if you're looking for fantastic pizza, you probably already have your go-to local pizza parlor in mind.

Really thrilled that I finally made it out to this place after over a year of knowing about it.  I really was organly blown away by what is the coolest pizza themed joint anywhere.  I love organs and it was simply fantastic to hear all the songs on this instrument housed in the skeleton of the building.  The pizza itself was just okay to me, but they have Blue Bell ice cream to make up for that!  And of course... the great promise of your favorite contemporary song being played on the organ.  Family fun, birthday fun...its organzmic!
Great place to come hang out & listen to music played on the organ! Especially during Christmas time!
Great food, good prices, fun atmosphere!  It does get crowded so expect a little wait.

This place was pretty entertaining!! The music varied including soundtrack hits from star wars and frozen. Pizza was alright, but crust not very good.  For two people it would be about $15 for a medium two topping pizza. Drinks are a bit pricey so I'll stick with water. Looking forward to going back

I ate here once for a retirement dinner for a friend, and once was enough.  The place was nasty dirty, the tables (that you eat on....) were the worst.  The pizza was pretty bad ( Eatza Pizza, Ci Cis, etc level) and to be honest I have had frozen pizzas that were better.  I find it disheartening that so many people rate this place based completely on the novelty, as I would rather have great food in a bland place then horrible food in a dirty place with a gimmick.   With all the diverse places and interesting food choices we have in this city, paying for really bad overpriced pizza in a place that they don't even bother to clean is silly - even if they do have a Organ.  And they only take cash? Seriously? My landscape guy even has a credit card machine in his truck, so why can't this place accept debit/credit?  Bottom line, ignore the novelty - if you want pizza go to Spinatos or Mellow Mushroom.

We received a gift certificate for Christmas and just recently decided to cash them in. This place is certainly unique and was a great dinner experience.  I expected the food to be subpar since the focus was on the entertainment but I was pleasantly surprised - the pizza was great!  The performance was fascinating. I don't know why it took us this long to go.  The two-line system is a bit weird, but the lines did move quickly.  Cash only, so make sure to hit the ATM before you go.

One of the fun places to eat pizza with the whole family. I have been coming here for many years now. Before the place opened I was able to get a grand tour of the whole background. It is absolutely unreal how much work they put into this place and how many gadgets and gizmos there are to create such entertainment. The musicians are amazing and I yet to hear a song they cannot play on the Organ and I love requesting certain songs for them to play. They have a ton of different sounds and instruments being played throughout the whole entire facility as well as many lights flashing all around you while you eat. Reminds me a little of Disneyland. Speaking of Disneyland I highly recommend a request for the great Musicians to play any Disney song you desire. Besides the entertainment, the food and especially the pizza taste completely different from anything you'll ever taste. I have tried pizza from all over and the thing I look for in all kinds of food is how different the food tastes. I want to make sure that I'm eating at a place where I cannot find a sequel to the taste and that's how I rate and everything that I eat. Whether somebody likes the place or not is their opinion because taste is always within the tongue of the beholder. Customer service is awesome here as well and I have never met any rude workers here as well. It's a great place to have a party it's a great place to bring your friends and family. It is on a cash only basis though so make sure you do bring your dollar bills and it is a dinner place so they usually open later so don't expect to go to lunch here. Make sure you check out this place and tell the managers Andrew Daniel from yelp sent you.

Always a great time when we come. Brought my mother in law this time. $35 for 3 pizza and two pitchers of soda and show well worth it. We heard phantom of the opera, Star Wars, Disney, and many more classic tunes. We can't recommend this place enough and can't wait for our next visit.

If you want to have a nice conversation over dinner, this is not the place to go.  If you are looking for quality pizza, this is not the place to go.  If you are looking for a place with some very unique entertainment to accompany some not-so-great pizza, than this is the place to go.  I love the entertainment.  The restaurant is built around the largest Wurlitzer theater pipe organ in the world (Almost 6,000 Pipes!). The organ controls violins, drums, horns, xylophones, and many other special effects hanging on the walls of the restaurant.  The music is a lot of fun. The organist plays movie scores, TV theme songs, Disney songs, Broadway hits, patriotic songs, and even takes requests!  Don't expect to be able to have a normal conversation since the noise is high volume.  The food is nothing special, so don't go expecting that and you won't leave disappointed.    Thanksgiving through Mid-April: Sunday - Thursday 4pm-9pm Friday - Saturday 4pm-10pm  Mid-April through Thanksgiving: Sunday - Thursday 5pm-9pm Friday - Saturday 5pm-10pm

OMG pizza is amazing by far the best pizza I've had hands down! Can't always go cause it's loud but defiantly family oriented, the atmospheres is really nice and everyone is friends HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
They don't accept cards. Debit or credit. Who doesn't accept cards now a days? So stupid. Pizza was mediocre. Would not come back

I took the kids here today; 9, 12 & 16 and they LOVED it!! This isn't a gourmet dining spot so if that's what you are looking, keep looking. I think the old cash registers, the different lines & old school salad bar give it a fun, eclectic feel! The kids enjoyed watching for their number, requesting songs, and signing along to the songs. The also loved the bench seating and the overall atmosphere. We all thought the pizza was pretty good and had no complaints. I would definitely bring them back here!

The pizza is just good but that's not why you should come here. The entertainment is unlike anything esle in the Valley. Anytime we have out of town guests, we alwasy suggest Organ Stop and no one has yet to be dissapointed. Good for adults and kids alike.

Finally got the chance to bring my parents here this past week after raving about it for more than a year. I inherited my dad's affinity for all things old and obscure, coin-operated player pianos and massive pipe organs among them. It was such a treat to see the look on his face while Lew Williams rocked the Mighty Wurlitzer.   We arrived to find a line going out the door (mostly senior citizens), but decided to tough it out. While waiting I ran into the main dining room, plucked one of the request cards, quickly wrote out "The Raiders of the Lost Ark theme song" before dropping it in the box and returning to our party.   I swear my dad nearly cried tears of pride and joy a few times, smiling broadly as we ate our amazingly savory large Combination (pepperoni, ham, bacon, sausage, beef, mushroom, olives, green pepper, onion) pizzas as we watched/listened to Lew playing.   It took a couple sets before Lew got to my request, but he played it at the very beginning of one before leading into a "Star Wars" medley, followed by the 1960s theme song to the "Star Trek." Indy has just always been near and dear to my family.   Someone recorded a previous performance (done by Charlie) and posted it on YouTube: http://youtu.be/Kh6HwkK2G7g  I do warn you, though, people can be extremely pushy when it comes to getting a table (since it's cafeteria-like seating) and sometimes they don't really care about the entertainment or common courtesy, either talking loudly over the music or standing in front of you while you're trying to watch.   Don't get down about it, though. Chances are they'll leave right after a set and won't sit through the short break. In the mean time, enjoy the music!

Well do not come here looking for good food... cause you aren't going to find it.  The pizza is no better than frozen and the salad bar leaves something to be desired.  Oddly enough... the onions rings were pretty good!    But the organ part of the evening makes up for what the food lacks.  It's quite the atmosphere.  The organ is amazing and it's fun to sing along and make requests!!

well its like this....very incredibly hokey, but really cool. I could picture this in pigeon forge or branson but it really is worth seeing. Pizza is OK (nothing Special) salad bar and Ice cream are also available...Amazing Pipe Organ+++ lots of extras...we drank several pitchers of beer
Wonderful food! Fun fun time. Spectacular music!  A must for visitors!!!  Have been here before and will come again. Highly recommend!!

So when a work holiday party gets scheduled at Organ Stop Pizza several things may come to your mind:  1. A funky pizza place that caters to the very young and the very old for a work function? Interesting. 2. Does this place deserve its Yelp Talk infamy? 3. Will Organ Stop Pizza make good on their title and make my organs stop when I eat their pizza?  There's so much cheesiness here and I'm not talking about the pizza! When there's flashing technicolor lights, a gigantic blingy overhead disco ball, and coordinated dancing cats wearing hats that bop to the beat of the pipe organ playing Chim Chim Cher-ee while said organ rotates around and around, what more could you ask for in a dining experience?   This humble restaurant is the "Home of the mighty Wurlitzer", an impressive looking pipe organ that dates back to the Roaring Twenties. The entire restaurant was rented out for us and we had an array of all you can eat salad, soda, pizza, and ice cream. The salad bar had all your standard dressings with an iceberg lettuce mix. The pizza was decent. It had a lightly crisp crust and puffy soft dough. It tasted about what you'd expect for a pizza buffet.  There were a lot of kids here since families were invited to the shindig, and they all seemed to enjoy the limitless pizza, soda and ice cream.   The star of the show is of course the pipe organ and organ player. Our organ player was Lew Williams who did an admirable job playing various songs by memory and even took requests from the audience. He played Christmas songs, a lot of Mary Poppins songs, some Disney, and the obligatory Phantom of the Opera numbers.   I wasn't really expecting that much from here but it was a decent experience. If you're looking for something that's definitely unique with a kitschy vibe, Organ Stop is your stop.

Organ player was amazing! He took requests and he is front and center so you can watch his talent. The food wasn't anything special...although the entire time we were there there was a line out the door and the staff were continuously working hard and being so timely with the food. Pizza was nice and hot. Other than that, it's a cafeteria feel, long benches, open seating.
Fun place. Menu is typical pizza joint, but the live organ music sets this gem apart from the rest.

The pizza is ok. But the music lights and ambience is why you go! Try the fried zucchini and don't forget ice cream.  We usually celebrate my Mom's birthday there every year.  They do the Birthday Song better than anyone else.  Bring cash they do not except credit or debit cards.  Dinner hours only.  A great family place!  Can accommodate large groups.

The sounds of the organ made my son have the best time. At 2 years old it was non stop head bopping and body shaking. It was an excellent time for him. Pizza was good but to see the smile on my sons face when listening to the organ made the night. This is an excellent place for a family fun night out. Just remember Thames don't take debit/credit but there is an ATM with a $2.50 service charge.

I have to give this place a 5!  It is amazing and it's not just the organ, it's also the pizza.  The pizza has definitely improved since we first visited several years ago.  We enjoyed visiting with friends and the organ.  Lights were everywhere.  Even the puppets came out to dance with the music.  Amazing for sure.  We ordered an Hawaiian pizza.  It was loaded with toppings and absolutely excellent.  We will definitely plan on taking other friends next time we visit.  That will be soon.

I love the cheese on their pizza. The salad bar is good, but I am a picky guy so maybe that's why. The best part of this whole place is their amazing organ artists. They place such amazing music and operate an astronomically elaborate machine!  The sounds rock!

We celebrated my daughters 3rd birthday here! We reserved a table for 20 on the main floor near the organ. The kids loved the music and lights! They danced they're little hearts out!! The adults were entertained as well, many had never been before.  They had a good mix of kid songs and adult ones.
